page.title: 11MAKING SILAGE AT PONTESBURY
page.content: The majority of farmers make silage in this area, instead of hay. They only make a small amount of hay to feed their calves. The silage is made in a clamp or pit, either dug into the ground or with purpose built sides. The grass is mown in May when the seeds are formed. It is left in the swath to wilt for a day, then it is chopped into short lengths by a forage harvester, the crop is then piled into the pit and rolled by a tractor to remove as much air as possible. This is then tightly sealed and left to heat up and turn into silage. The other method rapidly gaining popularity is big bag silage. The wilted grass is baled by a big baler and the bale sealed into a polythene bag. Each bale weighs about half a ton and is carried on a tractor spike.
